Problem:
Given a linear system governed by the differential equation \( \dot{x} = Mx \), where \( M \) is a constant matrix, consider examining the impact of the linear transformation \( T(x) = Qx \) for a matrix \( Q \). We investigate how this affects the system across different time points.

If at a certain time \( t_1 \), a new function \( S(x) = Px \) (where \( P \) is another constant matrix) is applied as an intervention, will the endpoint \( x(T) \) for \( T > t_1 \) depend only on \( M \) and not on \( Q \) or \( P \)?
Explanation: The intervention with \( S(x) \) introduces another layer of complexity, making the final state \( x(T) \) dependent on \( Q \), \( P \), and \( M \). The linear transformations \( T(x) \) and \( S(x) \) shape the trajectory of the system, influencing the endpoint \( x(T) \).
